THE NEWS LETTER
VOL. XV, NO. 24.

JUNIORS WIN DEBATE
Handicapped Senior Team Goes Down
to Defeat Carter Wins Adams
Medal.

The annual interclass debate between the junior and senior classes
was won on Friday night by the
junior class. The Adams medal,
the prize for public speaking offered to members of the class of
1913, was won by Mr. Paul Owens
Carter, who delivered "A Plea for
Cuba," by John M. Thurston.
McCoy Hall was crowded, and
the audience was exceedingly appreciative and enthusiastic. Dr.
John C. French presided, as he has
done for several years. The exercises were opened by a selection,
"Every Little Movement," played
by the University Musical Clubs.
This was followed immediately by
the Adams medal contest,the judges
for which were Rev. Clayton H.
Ranck, Prof. Arthur 0. Lovejoy,
and Prof. Robert M. Gay. The
contestants spoke upon the following subjects: Mr. John Earle Uhler, "For the. Child's Hospital," by
Charles Dickens; Mr. Louis Brodie,
"The Washington Memorial Arch,"
by G. W. Curtis; Mr. Paul Owens
Carter,"A Plea for Cuba," by John
\ I . Thurston, and Mr. John Sharpe
Dickinson on "The Expunging Resolution," by Henry Clay.
Following the contest a trio,
.\ I arche Militaire," was played by
\ I essrs. Ray, Gminder, and Warner, of the Instrumental Club.
The subject of the class debate
"as: "Resolved, That the present
disti ibution of powers between .the
Federal and State governments
should be revised in pursuance of
a policy of further centralization."
The senior team, for the affirmative,
consisted of Mr. Robert E. Miller,
chairman; Mr. Richard N. Mullikin, Mr. Leo Wolman, Mr. Harold
B. Hering, alternate, and Mr.Taylor
Starck, adviser. The junior team,
for the negative, consisted of Mr.
Alfred C. Hatch, Mr. Thomas B.
Price, chairman; 1\1 r. Lindsay Rogers, M r. William 0. Weyforth, Jr.,
alternate, and Mr. Bertram Benedict, adviser. The judges were Dr.
George Radcliffe, Dr. Horace E.
Flack,and Mr. Addison E. Mullikin.
After the debate selections from
"Professor Napoleon" were,'rendered by the Instrumental Club.
The announcement of awards was
then made by the judges. The
prizes are the Adams medal to the
winner of the public-speaking contest, and the Adams trophy to the
team winning the debate.
The speaking contest was one of
the best in years. The preliminary
trials were so close that fotm eon-

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 27, 1911.
testants in place of the usual three
were chosen. The selection given
by Mr. Carter was an extract from
a speech delivered in Congress just
before American intervention in
Cuba. It was full of oratorical effects and appeals to the emotions,
and was admirably adapted to the
round, mellow voice of the speaker.
The debate was not so close as
many had expected it would be.
One reason for this was the sudden
change that had to be made in the
senior team the week of the debate.
Mr. Wolman, the rebuttal man, was
unable to be present, owing to a
death in the family, and Mr. Hering
was forced to step in and prepare
the whole debate in four days. Naturally, this handicapped the team
materially. However, the junior
team won on its merits. The
shrewdness with which they conceded certain points in order to gain
others and the alertness which enabled them to point out where the
seniors had strayed somewhat from
the subject, won the debate. Another important factor in their victory was Rogers' rebuttal speech.
Those of us who know him were
somewhat surprised at the calm
self-restraint and sober judgment
with which he demolished his opponents' arguments one by one. It is
indeed very fortunate that we have
such able men as there were present
on both sides in defending our honor
against Gettysburg and WashingT. S.
ton and Lee next month.
Track Practice.

During the past four or five
weeks, the track men have been
showing a rather slovenly, lazy
spirit, and have been coming to
practice very irregularly. Only a
month away we have our first dual
meet, and in another week we have
the relay races at the University
of Pennsylvania. We need men
and the men need training to make
a success of these events. The
chance Hopkins has to win these
events is splendid if the men who
have ability will shbw the proper
interest. Every one can try; but
if those who can run, will not, how
can we expect to get out new men
to take interest in something which
is not carried on enthusiastically
now. Just come out and work, and
we will add new banners to our
trophy-room this spring for a certainty.
Vanderbilt University a few
weeks ago presented "The College
Widow."
C. E. Sweitzer, 'o8, is teaching at
the Shippensburg Normal School,
Shippensburg, Pa.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

TENNIS SCHEDULE ARRANGED

LACROSSE TEAM NEARLY READY

Manager Belt Announces a Partial Schedule for Hopkins' First Tennis
Team.

Bill Schmeisser Is on the Field Helping
to Knock the Corners Off Some
of the Ragged Play.

It has been felt for some time
that Hopkins could have a successful tennis team. This year, since
good material is abundant and the
students enthusiastic, plans for a
team have been fully developed.
The team will be composed of four
or six men—the best that can be
selected. The trips away from
home are to be financed by the players themselves, as the Athletic
Board probably would not support
both the tennis teams and the regular spring tournament.
Last week Manager Belt arranged several interesting matches.
He announces his schedule as follows:
April 28—Open.
May 3—Navy, at Annapolis.
May Io—Maryland Athletic Club,
at Maryland Athletic Club.
May 17—Western Maryland College, at Westminster.
May 24—Open.
It is quite probable that St. John's
and George Washington College
will be played on the two open
dates. The manager is sorry to
say that, because of the lack of guarantee money, offers of matches from
Harvard, Columbia, and Pennsylvania had to be declined. Such
matches at Homewood would have
proved a great attraction, and it is
to be hoped that next year Hopkins
may have the chance of meeting
these Northern colleges.
During the Easter holidays the
tennis courts at Homewood will be
put in use, and opportunity will be
given everyone to get into practice
for the college tournament. The
tournament is to begin some time
toward the end of May. The
matches will not be confined to the
undergraduates alone, but the medical men will have a chance to enter
also. Considering the number of
good players now at the University,
the final rounds should be highly
exciting.

The lacrosse team is now quickly
rounding into shape for the game
with Navy, which is only a few
days off. The coaches have the
men out every day, and when the
game comes off they will be in tiptop shape. Although Keith, the
medical student who was supposed
to hold down the first defense position is not coming out, the coaches
are working several men in that
place. The attack is still a little
weak in the midfield positions, but
the veteran, "Bill" Schmeisser, is
now taking them in hand, and when
he gets hold of them it is certain
that they will play better when the
time for the game comes. "Bill" is
a regular live wire on the team.
When he is there the team plays
with vim. Although the men have
not been able to play on the big
field as yet, Mr. Chalk has erected
goal posts on a field about half a
mile from the clubhouse. This helps
to get the team in trim, as they run
to the field and back again when
practice is over.
The team will be picked from
the following: Captain Hulbert,
Schmeisser, Hopkins, Gillet, Stockett, Kline, Tappan, Huck, Gail, Easter, Benedict, Niles, Ellicott, Bridgman, Everton, Makel, Sears, Sutton, Richardson, and Rosenthal.
Wolf is still on the injured list and
will not be able to play for the first
few games, but will be in shape in
time for the league games.
The scrub team has its schedule
all arranged and will play the first
game on April 1, at Mount Washington, against the Mount Washington Reserves. There will be
medals given out to the winning
team in the league. The Hopkins
Scrubs have a good team and are
in hopes of getting the medals.

The Laennec, the society for the
study of tuberculbsis, will hold. a
meeting tonight in the medical amphitheater at 8.15 o'clock. The
meeting will be commemorative of
Dr. Robert Koch. Papers will be
read by Dr. William H. Welch on
"The Influence of Koch and His
Students," and by Dr. W. M. Ford
and Dr. S. A. Knopff, of New York.
It looks as though Prof. Alphonsus Smith,'93, and his wife's gown
were working the spotlight overtime.

Both the lacrosse and baseball
teams play the corresponding Harvard teams at Homewood, April
15.
Professor Dabney, dean of the
graduate school at the University
of Virginia, thinks that intellectual
idealism has been sacrificed to athleticism in our American colleges.

press an unofficial statement is
made that the holidays at Easter
will be extended to two weeks.

.THE NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 27, 1911
COMMUNICATIONS
(THE NEWS-LETTER is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length'
upon topics of interest in the University
circles. Alumni especially are urged to
make use of this column.)
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.

I was much interested in an editorial in your issue of February 27
concerning the difficulty that the
medical students have in obtaining
proper medical treatment without
paying the full fees of the physicians whom they consult. But
more especially was I interested in
your statement that medical attention for students was arranged for
by other institutions, and your hope
that Hopkins would not allow itself
to remain remiss in this respect.
In your issue of March 13 "A
Graduate Student" tells of the difficulty and expense that especially attends the graduate students when
seeking medical advice.
I feel that you are unfair toward
the authorities of the medical school
in this matter, and beg to call your
attention to the following paragraphs, which I quote from the last
catalogue of the medical department. (The Johns Hopkins University Circular, Series of 1910, No.
9, pp. 116-117.)
MEDICAL ATTENTION TO STUDENTS.
"By the action of the Board of
Trustees of the University, taken
March 7, 1904, the appointment of
an official medical adviser to the students of the medical department was
authorized. This officer is to have
a definite hour for consultation with
medical students; is to be prepared
to visit in their own homes, when
called upon, such. students as are
unable to meet him at his consultation hour, and to obtain, when necessary, the services of specialists for
special examination and treatment.
This medical service is to be without cost to the students, the salary
of the, adviser being paid by the
medical department of the Univer sity. For the present academic year
Dr. T. R. BOMTS, resident physician
and associate in medicine in the
Johns Hopkins University, has been
appointed to this position.
"In order to guard more carefully
the health of the students the Advisory Board of the Medical Faculty
decided that, beginning with the
session of 1909-10, all entering students would be asked to undergo a
medical examination. Each student
is asked to report to one of a group
of selected physicians. A careful
physical examination is made and
the results are recorded and placed
upon file. If the results are unsatisfactory, the student is given appropriate advice in regard to his future
work.
"The Board decided also to appoint a competent physician to make
a sanitary examination of all boarding houses which advertise for the
patronage of the medical students.
A list of these houses which satisfy
the requirements of this inspection
as regards hygienic conditions is
posted in the office of the medical
school."

Thus I think it will be evident to
you that the authorities of the medical school have gone even farther
in this matter of medical attention
to students than you have wished
for.
When I was a student in the
medical school, and this was before the above arrangement was effected, I had no difficulty whatsoever in obtaining satisfactory medical attention on the two or three occasions upon which I needed it, and
without any expense, too. I am
connected with a small medical col7
lege at the present time, and am
always glad to do whatever I can
professionally for any student who
may call upon me and never. think
of charging him a cent. I am under the impression that my colleagues take the same view of the
matter, though I am not positive as
to this.
As for the graduate students,
their case is somewhat different, but
any physician is usually perfectly
willing to make a reduction in his
ordinary charges when the occasion
demands it. The individuals spoken
of by your correspondent were
probably victims of their own false
modesty, though, on the other
hand, the sum mentioned (Sic)) is
not great when compared with loss
of eyesight.
Inasmuch as the above arrangement has been made for the medical
students, it would probably not be
difficult to extend its provisions so
as to include all the students in the
University who have no regular
medical adviser. The authorities
would no doubt gladly take such action if a sufficient demand for it was
expressed. I would suggest that
you obtain an expression of opinion on this point from President
Remsen, himself a physician, and
from Dr. J. W. Williams, the dean
of the Medical Faculty.
AN ALUMNUS,
A. B. 1897, M. D. 190i.

Mary Johnston

New York Alumni Dine.

The New York Alumni Association of which Dr. Simon Flexner is
president held its annual dinner on
Friday night. The dinner was attended by about 75 men. Governor
Wilson, of New Jersey, was unable
to come because the legislature is
now in session.
After Dr. Flexner had been reelected president and the other business of the association had been
transacted, the men sat down to dinner. The cover of the menu cards
was in blue, the printing in black
and the leaves were held together
with cords of blue and black.
The toasts and speakers were:
"The University," President Ira
Rernsen ;"The Anti-Vivisection Agitation," Dr. Simon Flexner; "Advertising the University," Charles
A. Boston; "On to Homewood,"
Dr. G. Canby Robinson. The toastmaster was Dr. Thomas W. Hastings.

The last of the Hopkins class
banquets was held at the New Howard Hotel Saturday night, when the
juniors, with nearly every member
of the class present, feasted, imbibed, and listened to speeches and
jokes until nearly midnight.
Mr. Frederick Collins Lee made
an ideal toastmaster, and presided
with rare grace and charm, especially toward the latter part of the
evening. Following are the speakers, whose toasts were named after
well-known publications:
"Everybody's," T. Brooke Price;
"Sporting Life," John S. Fulton,
Jr.; "Boston Cook Book," with special reference to "Chicken," John G.
Huck, Jr.; "Popular Mechanics,"
and "Common Sense," Gabriel H.
Todes.
Mr. Williams Haynes, who was
to have spoken on "Life," was not
present, and so his toast was filled
by the lately lamented Frank Beehler, who fell by the wayside. "The
Woman's World," on which H.
Norman Cole was to have spoken,
was taken by William Gail, who explained the mysteries of hemstitching. Mr. Lindsay Rogers read some
poetry, which he claimed was original and humorous, as a response to
his toast on "The New York Evening Journal."
In addition to these, there were
a number of impromptu speeches,
and each one present told some
"jokes." So far as is known, there
were no casualties. One full-dress
suit and one Tuxedo were in evidence.
The committee which arranged
the banquet and to whom credit is
due for the success of the affair
consisted of Donald K. Belt, chairman; Ellis Miller, and J. G. Huck.
Each member present received an
attractive-looking card case as a
favor.

THE NEWS LETTER

JUNIORS WIN DEBATE
Handicapped Senior Team Goes Down
to Defeat Carter Wins Adams
Medal.

The annual interclass debate between the junior and senior classes
was won on Friday night by the
junior class. The Adams medal,
the prize for public speaking offered to members of the class of
1913, was won by Mr. Paul Owens
Carter, who delivered "A Plea for
Cuba," by John M. Thurston.
McCoy Hall was crowded, and
the audience was exceedingly appreciative and enthusiastic. Dr.
John C. French presided, as he has
done for several years. The exercises were opened by a selection,
"Every Little Movement," played
by the University Musical Clubs.
This was followed immediately by
the Adams medal contest,the judges
for which were Rev. Clayton H.
Ranck, Prof. Arthur 0. Lovejoy,
and Prof. Robert M. Gay. The
contestants spoke upon the following subjects: Mr. John Earle Uhler, "For the. Child's Hospital," by
Charles Dickens; Mr. Louis Brodie,
"The Washington Memorial Arch,"
by G. W. Curtis; Mr. Paul Owens
Carter,"A Plea for Cuba," by John
\ I . Thurston, and Mr. John Sharpe
Dickinson on "The Expunging Resolution," by Henry Clay.
Following the contest a trio,
.\ I arche Militaire," was played by
\ I essrs. Ray, Gminder, and Warner, of the Instrumental Club.
The subject of the class debate
"as: "Resolved, That the present
disti ibution of powers between .the
Federal and State governments
should be revised in pursuance of
a policy of further centralization."
The senior team, for the affirmative,
consisted of Mr. Robert E. Miller,
chairman; Mr. Richard N. Mullikin, Mr. Leo Wolman, Mr. Harold
B. Hering, alternate, and Mr.Taylor
Starck, adviser. The junior team,
for the negative, consisted of Mr.
Alfred C. Hatch, Mr. Thomas B.
Price, chairman; 1\1 r. Lindsay Rogers, M r. William 0. Weyforth, Jr.,
alternate, and Mr. Bertram Benedict, adviser. The judges were Dr.
George Radcliffe, Dr. Horace E.
Flack,and Mr. Addison E. Mullikin.
After the debate selections from
"Professor Napoleon" were,'rendered by the Instrumental Club.
The announcement of awards was
then made by the judges. The
prizes are the Adams medal to the
winner of the public-speaking contest, and the Adams trophy to the
team winning the debate.
The speaking contest was one of
the best in years. The preliminary
trials were so close that fotm eon-

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 27, 1911.
testants in place of the usual three
were chosen. The selection given
by Mr. Carter was an extract from
a speech delivered in Congress just
before American intervention in
Cuba. It was full of oratorical effects and appeals to the emotions,
and was admirably adapted to the
round, mellow voice of the speaker.
The debate was not so close as
many had expected it would be.
One reason for this was the sudden
change that had to be made in the
senior team the week of the debate.
Mr. Wolman, the rebuttal man, was
unable to be present, owing to a
death in the family, and Mr. Hering
was forced to step in and prepare
the whole debate in four days. Naturally, this handicapped the team
materially. However, the junior
team won on its merits. The
shrewdness with which they conceded certain points in order to gain
others and the alertness which enabled them to point out where the
seniors had strayed somewhat from
the subject, won the debate. Another important factor in their victory was Rogers' rebuttal speech.
Those of us who know him were
somewhat surprised at the calm
self-restraint and sober judgment
with which he demolished his opponents' arguments one by one. It is
indeed very fortunate that we have
such able men as there were present
on both sides in defending our honor
against Gettysburg and WashingT. S.
ton and Lee next month.
Track Practice.

During the past four or five
weeks, the track men have been
showing a rather slovenly, lazy
spirit, and have been coming to
practice very irregularly. Only a
month away we have our first dual
meet, and in another week we have
the relay races at the University
of Pennsylvania. We need men
and the men need training to make
a success of these events. The
chance Hopkins has to win these
events is splendid if the men who
have ability will shbw the proper
interest. Every one can try; but
if those who can run, will not, how
can we expect to get out new men
to take interest in something which
is not carried on enthusiastically
now. Just come out and work, and
we will add new banners to our
trophy-room this spring for a certainty.
Vanderbilt University a few
weeks ago presented "The College
Widow."
C. E. Sweitzer, 'o8, is teaching at
the Shippensburg Normal School,
Shippensburg, Pa.

TENNIS SCHEDULE ARRANGED

LACROSSE TEAM NEARLY READY

Manager Belt Announces a Partial Schedule for Hopkins' First Tennis
Team.

Bill Schmeisser Is on the Field Helping
to Knock the Corners Off Some
of the Ragged Play.

It has been felt for some time
that Hopkins could have a successful tennis team. This year, since
good material is abundant and the
students enthusiastic, plans for a
team have been fully developed.
The team will be composed of four
or six men—the best that can be
selected. The trips away from
home are to be financed by the players themselves, as the Athletic
Board probably would not support
both the tennis teams and the regular spring tournament.
Last week Manager Belt arranged several interesting matches.
He announces his schedule as follows:
April 28—Open.
May 3—Navy, at Annapolis.
May Io—Maryland Athletic Club,
at Maryland Athletic Club.
May 17—Western Maryland College, at Westminster.
May 24—Open.
It is quite probable that St. John's
and George Washington College
will be played on the two open
dates. The manager is sorry to
say that, because of the lack of guarantee money, offers of matches from
Harvard, Columbia, and Pennsylvania had to be declined. Such
matches at Homewood would have
proved a great attraction, and it is
to be hoped that next year Hopkins
may have the chance of meeting
these Northern colleges.
During the Easter holidays the
tennis courts at Homewood will be
put in use, and opportunity will be
given everyone to get into practice
for the college tournament. The
tournament is to begin some time
toward the end of May. The
matches will not be confined to the
undergraduates alone, but the medical men will have a chance to enter
also. Considering the number of
good players now at the University,
the final rounds should be highly
exciting.

The lacrosse team is now quickly
rounding into shape for the game
with Navy, which is only a few
days off. The coaches have the
men out every day, and when the
game comes off they will be in tiptop shape. Although Keith, the
medical student who was supposed
to hold down the first defense position is not coming out, the coaches
are working several men in that
place. The attack is still a little
weak in the midfield positions, but
the veteran, "Bill" Schmeisser, is
now taking them in hand, and when
he gets hold of them it is certain
that they will play better when the
time for the game comes. "Bill" is
a regular live wire on the team.
When he is there the team plays
with vim. Although the men have
not been able to play on the big
field as yet, Mr. Chalk has erected
goal posts on a field about half a
mile from the clubhouse. This helps
to get the team in trim, as they run
to the field and back again when
practice is over.
The team will be picked from
the following: Captain Hulbert,
Schmeisser, Hopkins, Gillet, Stockett, Kline, Tappan, Huck, Gail, Easter, Benedict, Niles, Ellicott, Bridgman, Everton, Makel, Sears, Sutton, Richardson, and Rosenthal.
Wolf is still on the injured list and
will not be able to play for the first
few games, but will be in shape in
time for the league games.
The scrub team has its schedule
all arranged and will play the first
game on April 1, at Mount Washington, against the Mount Washington Reserves. There will be
medals given out to the winning
team in the league. The Hopkins
Scrubs have a good team and are
in hopes of getting the medals.

The Laennec, the society for the
study of tuberculbsis, will hold. a
meeting tonight in the medical amphitheater at 8.15 o'clock. The
meeting will be commemorative of
Dr. Robert Koch. Papers will be
read by Dr. William H. Welch on
"The Influence of Koch and His
Students," and by Dr. W. M. Ford
and Dr. S. A. Knopff, of New York.
It looks as though Prof. Alphonsus Smith,'93, and his wife's gown
were working the spotlight overtime.

Both the lacrosse and baseball
teams play the corresponding Harvard teams at Homewood, April
15.
Professor Dabney, dean of the
graduate school at the University
of Virginia, thinks that intellectual
idealism has been sacrificed to athleticism in our American colleges.

press an unofficial statement is
made that the holidays at Easter
will be extended to two weeks.

(THE NEWS-LETTER is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length'
upon topics of interest in the University
circles. Alumni especially are urged to

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.

I was much interested in an editorial in your issue of February 27
concerning the difficulty that the
medical students have in obtaining
proper medical treatment without
paying the full fees of the physicians whom they consult. But
more especially was I interested in
your statement that medical attention for students was arranged for
by other institutions, and your hope
that Hopkins would not allow itself
to remain remiss in this respect.
In your issue of March 13 "A
Graduate Student" tells of the difficulty and expense that especially attends the graduate students when
seeking medical advice.
I feel that you are unfair toward
the authorities of the medical school
in this matter, and beg to call your
attention to the following paragraphs, which I quote from the last
catalogue of the medical department. (The Johns Hopkins University Circular, Series of 1910, No.
9, pp. 116-117.)
MEDICAL ATTENTION TO STUDENTS.
"By the action of the Board of
Trustees of the University, taken
March 7, 1904, the appointment of
an official medical adviser to the students of the medical department was
authorized. This officer is to have
a definite hour for consultation with
medical students; is to be prepared
to visit in their own homes, when
called upon, such. students as are
unable to meet him at his consultation hour, and to obtain, when necessary, the services of specialists for
special examination and treatment.
This medical service is to be without cost to the students, the salary
of the, adviser being paid by the
medical department of the Univer sity. For the present academic year
Dr. T. R. BOMTS, resident physician
and associate in medicine in the
Johns Hopkins University, has been
appointed to this position.
"In order to guard more carefully
the health of the students the Advisory Board of the Medical Faculty
decided that, beginning with the
session of 1909-10, all entering students would be asked to undergo a
medical examination. Each student
is asked to report to one of a group
of selected physicians. A careful
physical examination is made and
the results are recorded and placed
upon file. If the results are unsatisfactory, the student is given appropriate advice in regard to his future
work.
"The Board decided also to appoint a competent physician to make
a sanitary examination of all boarding houses which advertise for the
patronage of the medical students.
A list of these houses which satisfy
the requirements of this inspection
as regards hygienic conditions is
posted in the office of the medical
school."

Thus I think it will be evident to
you that the authorities of the medical school have gone even farther
in this matter of medical attention
to students than you have wished
for.
When I was a student in the
medical school, and this was before the above arrangement was effected, I had no difficulty whatsoever in obtaining satisfactory medical attention on the two or three occasions upon which I needed it, and
without any expense, too. I am
connected with a small medical col7
lege at the present time, and am
always glad to do whatever I can
professionally for any student who
may call upon me and never. think
of charging him a cent. I am under the impression that my colleagues take the same view of the
matter, though I am not positive as
to this.
As for the graduate students,
their case is somewhat different, but
any physician is usually perfectly
willing to make a reduction in his
ordinary charges when the occasion
demands it. The individuals spoken
of by your correspondent were
probably victims of their own false
modesty, though, on the other
hand, the sum mentioned (Sic)) is
not great when compared with loss
of eyesight.
Inasmuch as the above arrangement has been made for the medical
students, it would probably not be
difficult to extend its provisions so
as to include all the students in the
University who have no regular
medical adviser. The authorities
would no doubt gladly take such action if a sufficient demand for it was
expressed. I would suggest that
you obtain an expression of opinion on this point from President
Remsen, himself a physician, and
from Dr. J. W. Williams, the dean
of the Medical Faculty.
AN ALUMNUS,
A. B. 1897, M. D. 190i.

Mary Johnston

New York Alumni Dine.

The New York Alumni Association of which Dr. Simon Flexner is
president held its annual dinner on
Friday night. The dinner was attended by about 75 men. Governor
Wilson, of New Jersey, was unable
to come because the legislature is
now in session.
After Dr. Flexner had been reelected president and the other business of the association had been
transacted, the men sat down to dinner. The cover of the menu cards
was in blue, the printing in black
and the leaves were held together
with cords of blue and black.
The toasts and speakers were:
"The University," President Ira
Rernsen ;"The Anti-Vivisection Agitation," Dr. Simon Flexner; "Advertising the University," Charles
A. Boston; "On to Homewood,"
Dr. G. Canby Robinson. The toastmaster was Dr. Thomas W. Hastings.

The last of the Hopkins class
banquets was held at the New Howard Hotel Saturday night, when the
juniors, with nearly every member
of the class present, feasted, imbibed, and listened to speeches and
jokes until nearly midnight.
Mr. Frederick Collins Lee made
an ideal toastmaster, and presided
with rare grace and charm, especially toward the latter part of the
evening. Following are the speakers, whose toasts were named after
well-known publications:
"Everybody's," T. Brooke Price;
"Sporting Life," John S. Fulton,
Jr.; "Boston Cook Book," with special reference to "Chicken," John G.
Huck, Jr.; "Popular Mechanics,"
and "Common Sense," Gabriel H.
Todes.
Mr. Williams Haynes, who was
to have spoken on "Life," was not
present, and so his toast was filled
by the lately lamented Frank Beehler, who fell by the wayside. "The
Woman's World," on which H.
Norman Cole was to have spoken,
was taken by William Gail, who explained the mysteries of hemstitching. Mr. Lindsay Rogers read some
poetry, which he claimed was original and humorous, as a response to
his toast on "The New York Evening Journal."
In addition to these, there were
a number of impromptu speeches,
and each one present told some
"jokes." So far as is known, there
were no casualties. One full-dress
suit and one Tuxedo were in evidence.
The committee which arranged
the banquet and to whom credit is
due for the success of the affair
consisted of Donald K. Belt, chairman; Ellis Miller, and J. G. Huck.
Each member present received an
attractive-looking card case as a
favor.
